reviewText:
THE BAD: Who's ♥♥♥♥ing idea was it to give every ♥♥♥♥ing enemy an attack that stuns Hiryu? If this isn't the biggest oversight in the ♥♥♥♥ing galaxy, I don't know what is. In a game that is built around speed and getting from one place to another quickly, getting hit by bullets you can't even ♥♥♥♥ing dodge and getting stunned for what seems like years is SO FRUSTRATING. This game is so fast paced, which is really good, but when you are losing your momentum every two seconds, you don't even want to play anymore. The first half of the game is good, but when freezing and plasma gets introduced, it's all ♥♥♥♥ing down hill. Also the music isn't good, and the story is 100% non-existent.

THE GOOD: On the other hand, the game feel is some of the best I've ever seen. Strider actually feels like a ninja, the way smoke comes off the ground when he jumps or runs, the way it actually feels how you're ripping through enemies with your swords, the teleportation thing is great and is so much fun to use with the double jump, etc. The graphics are very unique and sexy as ♥♥♥♥. The pacing in the game is really good and Strider gets new abilities every fifteen minutes of play which is enough time to master the last ability and use it in tandem with the new ability. Lastly, it's a quick play, but lots of things for completionists.

TLDR: Getting stunned literally ruins the game, but if you want a fast-paced game and want to feel like a ninja, Strider will do the job easily.

4/5

reviewText: Wow, this game is fantastic. Having played the original NES Strider and the Genesis Strider, I have to say this game is an absolutely fantastic reboot. It has the open-world feel of the original NES classic but with much better level (and graphic) design, and has the quality of color and atmospheric charm of the Genesis version but with far better view instead of the absurdly close-up shots of Strider Hiryu at the benefit of graphical fidelity. Besides that the game is clean and crisp. It's a joy to play and although at first it may seem too easy (there are difficulty options), that's just a nice way to lull you into the fact that this game requires a lot of strategy. While you start with these clunky combos and button-mashing slaying of any of the Kazakh guards you see, their tactics and yours have to evolve to suit the multi-levelled terrain, the new equipment and abilities both you and the enemies get, and your general skill. The better you get, the more the game begins to feel like a brutal ballet where Strider vaults over enemies and cuts everything in his path with effortless grace. The story is far better than that of its originals since now there's not only voice acting but it's actually got a cohesive and tangible plot this time that isn't arbitrarily sending you across the world in a weirdly specific set of locations with little backstory.\n\nOverall, this is a very fun game. I really recommend it.

reviewText:
Strider is a patron saint of the 2D arcade pantheon, that I have a little shrine to in my heart. If you remember how awesome the attract mode of the original looked back in '88, then you know how awesome this game will make you feel.

Fluid physics; graceful controls. The best Sci-Fi Metroidvania since Shadow Complex. I was deeply skeptical of this game, and it proved me wrong again and again. The swordplay is like a blend of SOTN and MMX - this is an incredible achievement. Well played, Capcom. For the first time in a decade, well played.

High points: deflecting almost anything with a plasma sword. Dashing through enemies to cause explosions. Sending explosive kunai into mechs. Listening to the excellent effects work, and noticing callbacks to twenty years of gaming. Riding a holographic plasma panther.

10/10, would buy again at full price.

reviewText: This is a 2D Side Scrolling Metroidvania-light with extensive melee combat, and a little bit of backtracking. The combat options are surprisingly deep, and the character is fairly acrobatic, leading to lots of off-the-main road explorations.  Boss battles are challenging but fair (although there was one near the end I really had trouble with), and there's enough reward for going back through the earlier levels that I added probably two hours to my game time backtracking (and still only ended with 85% completion). The story is really slight, but that isn't the point of the game. There are some issues (only one save slot, and you can't go back to explore more after finishing the game; travel between sections for backtracking takes a lot more work than it should), but overall it's a fun, challenging action adventure.

reviewText:
Strider was a very fun and enjoyable action side scroller. Filled with beautiful lighting and fast paced fights, it reminded me of the old days of NES and SNES titles like Metroid and Megaman, along with the (of course) previous installments in the Strider franchise. (Which I have not yet gotten a chance to try personally.) I encourage the use of a controller with this game, but those on the keyboard should be able to manage.

Liked:
-Fun
-Fast
-Fluid
-Metroidvania
-Level design (in general*)

Disliked:
-Stun locks
-Poorly designed invisible walls*
-Unengaging story
-Questionable voice acting
-Anti-climatic ending
-Saving at the end of the game stops you from going back and collecting everything. Is an option not to save however. (Awesome reward for beating the final boss... /sarcasm)

Overall Score: 6/10

reviewText:
While I did enjoy this game, it comes with a few things that to me felt like grievous issues.

Cons:
Camera - The camera is almsot always fine, but in a few boss fights it zooms in and out at horrible times and pulls away from the boss to follow Strider.  It's even worse around gravity globes you can run on, which are their own irritating issue that just becomes more annoying.

No invincibility frames - A few normal enemies and a few boss attacks have their entire gimmick around this and squeezing as much damage as possible in one volley or chain stuns.  Easily a quarter or more of a fully upgraded health from one of those, or just getting pinballed between 2-4 enemies for a few seconds while you wait for the chance to have control again.

Other smaller issues involve the final tower level being a boring difficulty spike and that wall climbing has you suddenly mantle up and over from a bit too generous of a distance.  Also there's an entire level where you run against the wind meaning you walk slow and jump short distances; meh.


The Good:
Movement is amazing.  Running, dashing, jumping, and sliding around while slashing everything in sight is solid and the best part of the game.  Worth a playthrough alone just to hop around and hit stuff really.


The Metroidvaia aspect feels tacked on with four flavors (ice, fire, reflect, magnetic/ranged) to the dash, slash, and kunais, but overall is fun while you do a little backtracking here and there and have a dramatic pose animation that plays each time you pick up an upgrade.  Also ignore the story.  Not because the story is really bad, but because it's just in the way of the fun and makes deaths to bosses involve watching another boring taunt speech.

For all of the negatives, I do still recommend this game oddly.  It's that much fun to play when the quirks aren't getting in your face.

reviewText: Like swords?  Remember the Striders running, jumping, doing the usual platformer mischief?  You're in luck!  From arcade to consoles, it's been a fun ride for Strider, and in Strider HD/Strider 2014, you get a quite-faithful modernization of the classic.  Upgrades and backtracking a bit for other unlockables, aren't too out of the way, but some require navigating with precise timing against hazards.  Others need prerequisite skills to reach.  Hey, like bosses that present at least a bit of challenge?  The boss fights aren't boring, and run from signle foes, multiple bosses at once, giant whirring mechanations, dazzling explosions, lasers, and mysticism which isn't terribly predictable, and will give you a feeling of accomplishment, in their death throes.  You'll be looking at your map to track down some unlockables, but despite the game having clearly defined locations to reach, you'll find yourself diverting to a far corner, to see if there's a bit of exploring to be had.  Controls at later levels, with skill unlocks, becomes very wide-open, and you'll be slashing through rows of baddies!\nNow, regarding the bad.  This game is known to be unstable on integrated/discrete video chips, but seems quite reliable with dedicated video cards.  Then, there's input; you may need a DirectX-XInput wrapper, like x360ce or others, so the game can see" your gamepad.  After this quick bit is tended to
date: you'll be enjoying the variety of enemies and tactics!  I generally think of reboots as trash
recommended: but this is one that is worthy of a few sessions on the couch."

reviewText:
Amazing, well planned and constructed maps; very visually appealing.  My only issue is with the play controls - I was expecting a loose control scheme, but was given a reactive-type instead.

For example:
When Strider gets close to a wall in midair, he reacts by grabbing onto the wall with his ninja tools.
When Strider attacks an enemy with a shield, the game reacts by slowing the game for effect while his weapon bounces off the shield and stuns him.
When Strider is struck in midair with practially anything, he reacts by falling to the ground and won't react until you've tried to jump several times.
When Strider stands on a gravity globe, the controls react depending on which side of the globe you're on and you have to change which direction to hold on the control stick in order to keep moving.  This is especially frustrating during the final boss fight in which not only are you jumping from gravity globe to gravity globe but you're dodging seemingly random attacks that all stun on impact whether you're airborne or not.

The game is great for what it is, but don't pick it up expecting a Metroidvania game - it's more a ninja-action game, which is really quite fitting the character and series.

reviewText:
Pros:+ Very tight and solid mechanics
~ The game is very fluid and natural. Has very satisfying feedback and feel when attacking and moving. Hiryu will attack as fast as you mash the button and mechanics like fast falling when pressing down in the air plus a brisk pace makes this feel great. The combat also feels solid with flashy and satisfying visual feedback when attacking enemies with sparks and bright colors flying everywhere.

+ Fast progression
~ You never feel like a segment is dragged out as you will constantly be unlocking power-ups. You also feel like a powered up badass if you decide to backtrack for collectibles with your upgrades in places you got your ♥♥♥ handed to before.

+ Tons of bosses and unlockables
~ If you like Metroidvania/Metroid-like games with a tons of bosses and unlockables, then this game will satisfy that desire. The actual upgrade collectibles are a small amount but you can unlock stuff like concept art, story info, and alternate skins/costumes.

+ Heavily inspired by Super Metroid in game design and progression, while keeping the feeling of being a badass ninja

+ Excellent mix of platforming and action
~ If you like platforming segments ontop of your action, this game has it in spades. Thankfully they aren't too tedious or challenging minus maybe one or two segments.

+ Old school game with shiny graphics

Cons:- Difficulty all over the place in boss battles
~ I played on hard, and playing the game and getting around areas never felt too difficult minus a few areas. The boss battles aren't very difficult until the latter half of the game, where the order of their patterns gets faster, more intense, and randomized. However, they do the same attack patterns even if they are out of order, so that helps a lot I guess

- Backtracking for upgrades and collectibles is time consuming due to lack of good overworld design/fast travel points
~ it's not too bad as there are fast travel points but it could be way better in terms of placement and where they take you

- Unbalanced sound design
The music isn't bad and actually fits the game pretty well, but it's nothing you'll be humming to any time soon. It is the lack of sound balance when fast traveling and attacking that puts this as a con. I put the volume up on my headphones because the base game was kind of quiet, but when you fast travel and attack it's like you're getting stabbed in your eardrums with sudden intense loud sound.

TL;DRThis game is an old school action/platformer made in the vein of Super Metroid/Metroidvanias. You feel like a badass ninja with tight mechanics and feedback. If you're one of those muh story and presentation" people when it comes to games
date: look elsewhere. If you want a good action sidescroller Metroid like game
recommended: play this right now; it's definitely one of the better options available."

reviewText: I'm not a big fan of classic Strider but I really dug this game. It's a neat marriage of the fast-paced slashy gameplay of the original and a Metroid-esque structure. Really good game with great, fluid and fun controls. The only real complaint I have is that the bosses kind of suck. If you try to learn their patterns they'll often blow you away with powerful attacks, but if you just go right up to them and mash buttons you'll almost always win. It's also sort of easy but not insultingly so. Those points aside it's highly recommended, it's a quick, frenetic and thoughtful platformer that doesn't wear out its welcome.

reviewText: Now I know who that guy from Marvel Vs. Capcom is. A pretty decent Metroidvania. Smooth graphics. Awesome upgrades. NIce aesthetic. The story is so awful I wonder if it was intentional. The problems I have with the game stem mostly from the progression (it felt somewhat open worldly, but it couldn't quite commit) and there are times where I feel like some bosses, stages, enemies, and parts were put in the game purely for padding to make it longer. That said, I quite enjoyed my experience and if anything, the combat in this game is really.♥♥♥♥ing.awesome!

reviewText: Very nice platformer with some unique ideas. Great boss fights and progression system. Could not put it down for 5h40 minutes until I finished it on Normal. Tomorrow I start new on Hard mode.\nYou play as a ninja and start with a basic attack then you can acquire more moves by finding collectibles and defeating bosses. There is a sort of elemental" mechanic to the weapon where you can channel a different form of energy through the sword or kunais (throwing weapon) and that changes their attack and each enemy is vunelrable to either a special move or a certain element or a combination of the two. The game also plays around with gravity making for very nice platforming unlike anything else.\nThe maps are huge and you can get almost anywhere on the map. I really mean everywhere
hoursPlayed:
you can go through floors or through the ceilings. You get a double jump and an additional boost attack getting in the end a sort of triple jump. The boost can also be used through a sort of gates transforming it superjumps that can be chained through multiple gates. Very fun.
The graphics are nice and animations look great.
The movement is fluid and so is the combat... with the exceptions of some moments in the end levels where enemies can chain freeze you and kill you without recourse (even on normal).
All in all a great game worth the price... I bought it for 1 dollar in a Humble Bundle :) but it certainly is worth far more."
